sub_title: Technical Product Manager at OMRON Healthcare Europe
summary:
My career motivation? Bringing awesome products to the world. Generating good with my work and solving social needs. Most importantly, seeing people benefit, or are happy, with the products I work on.

As a person with a myriad of interests, I took a few years changing departments to find out what I wanted to do. Something about Product Management stood out to me. I enjoyed being that unwavering bridge between development and business requirements. While (some) business people shy away from engineering, and vice versa, thanks to my interest in both fields, I thoroughly enjoy being this demanding middleman. even if it means sometimes having to speak almost two languages to convey the same thing to different stakeholders. What initially seemed like a set back to others (hopping departments), has most definitely been advantageous for me to develop an effective way to communicate with various stakeholders.

My experience extends even to my teenage years, where I started developing work skills in a multitude of areas by helping out at my family's businesses as an welfare administrator, a social media marketing executive, and an e-commerce executive, all at once. I then graduated with a degree in computer science, tried my hand in UIUX to follow my passion in user experience and design, before landing a job in Omron Healthcare as a service business developer, and later a product owner. 

I'm confident to say that I am a resourceful, fast learner, that I have an eye for both the long term big picture AND tiny details, and that I take pride and responsibility in my daily work. I am also not afraid to voice my opinions, to take initiative, and to challenge the norms of business operations (such as cutting out unnecessary approval and processes...). I am an efficiency seeker.

It is important to me that my work contributes to society, be it bettering the health of people like my work at Omron, or solving societal needs, or simply making people happy. In my career, I fondly look back at the time I offered my skills to non-profits, and educated the next generation as a programming teacher. In the long run, I'd like to explore how my employer or my work is able to help less privileged communities and create sustainable businesses with a cause.
